content.content: Overview We have had some interesting weeks regarding the System Surplus Buffer and before going into the details of this Signal Request I would like to give a brief overview of the events:  In late November, an executive passed to slowly increase the Surplus Buffer from 60MM to 90MM by 1MM a week with the intention to burn a bit of the revenues while constantly increasing the System Surplus. You can find the corresponding onchain poll here, and the previous Signal Request here  On 2022-01-21T23:00:00Z a large market downturn led to a lot of vault liquidations resulting in a lot of Flap auctions as the System Surplus exceeded the configured Surplus Buffer. Maker collected ~15 MM DAI in penalty fees, over 400 Flap auctions have been triggered - most of them running in parallel. A lot of them ended with a huge discount, resulting in an estimated inefficiency of 2.1 MM. A more detailed deep dive can be found here. On 2022-01-23T23:00:00Z I posted an Urgent Signal Request to discontinue the slow increase of the Surplus Buffer and replace it with directly setting it to 250 MM to prevent any further burning of MKR. On the same day, @Protocol-Engineering  and @GovAlpha-Core-Unit  placed an out-of-schedule executive into the voting portal reflecting the changes by the Urgent Signal Request This passed within 16 minutes and the spell got cast on 2022-01-25T23:00:00Z  On 2022-01-24T23:00:00Z I posted another Signal Request with an option to go back to the previous setting, with the addition to include a Rate Limiting into the Flapper-Module, which would limit the amount of parallel Flap-Auctions. The Signal Request passed with a majority in favor of introducing the Rate-Limited Flapper and returning to MKR burning.  While the overview section of the Signal Request explicitly stated the intention of going back to the same lerp mechanics as before, the details on the voting option did not. We ended up with an onchain-poll that will just add the Rate Limiter to the Flapper Module, but not going back to the same Surplus Buffer configuration. This Signal Request is to decide if we want to return to the configuration we had before (see corresponding executive) - lerping up from 60 MM to 90 MM with 1MM/week If we want to return to the old config, there are a couple of prerequisites that need to be met before the change can get executed:  the Rate Limiter needs to get installed in mainnet - this will take a couple of weeks we need an initial configuration for the Rate Limiter  Please note that in any case we are not going to see any MKR burning in the next weeks, as returning to the previous configuration will restart with a Surplus Buffer well above (> 10 MM) the current System Surplus. There is no need to rush this decision, so I would like to run this Signal Request longer than usual.  Shall we return to the previous partial burning as agreed in November? This will restore the IAM we set up for slowly increasing the Surplus Buffer in November 2021 from 60MM to 90MM (backdated start date 2021-11-28T23:00:00Z) over the course of 210 days but only after  the Rate Limiter has been installed in mainnet - this will take a couple of weeks an initial configuration for the Rate Limiter has been set   Pros  we will continue with the partial burning as soon as the System Surplus is back exceeding the Surplus Buffer - returning to the state we all agreed on before partial burning will increase the buy-pressure on the illiquid MKR market on a huge market decline a lot of MKR will get bought (we cannot configure the Rate Limiting below 1.44MM/day)   Cons  Some of the profit will not get directed into growing our product but instead towards MKR holders      Yes No Abstain     0 voters      Next Steps The Polls will run until 2022-03-03T23:00:00Z ; its outcome will either result in an on-chain-poll assuming the outcome of the poll deems it necessary or its intermediate result is going to be taken to another initiative - another signal, onchain-poll or urgency executive. PS: thanks to @PaperImperium @MakerMan and @JustinCase  for collaboration on this Signal Request.  A little personal note here I have been (silently) advocating for no MKR burn for a couple of months, but I accepted and was fine with the decision to have at least some partial burning. But my opinion doesn’t matter a lot here - I have a different point to make: We should not use an urgent adjustment made to the protocol’s configuration to justify switching directions. We shall not abandon established processes around decision making. If the community wants to stop MKR burning at all - that’s fine. But this needs to be a structured decision. As I have been the guy pushing for the urgent-change, I feel responsibility to follow up on the path of moving out of it.

content.content: ultraschuppi:  @brianmcmichael had a very interesting idea how we could avoid this, unsure if he wants to talk about it already    So I’ve just published an early prototype of dss-kiln. This is a single-purpose burner contract that allows governance to set a lot and a hop value, then governance can suck some amount of Dai from the surplus buffer to the kiln where it will be burned off over time by making direct swaps against an AMM contract. For example, MKR governors might set the lot at 30,000 Dai and the hop at 6 hours. Some amount can be sucked from the surplus buffer to the kiln contract where a keeper can call the fire() function every 6 hours to sell 30,000 Dai on an AMM and burn the resulting MKR. This allows governance to strategically burn Dai over time and ensure that the trades execute at market instead of OTC. The current (unaudited please don’t use) prototype includes code for trading on Uniswap V2 and on Uniswap V3. In the case of the former, liquidity on the MKR/DAI pair is very thin and would need to be reinforced by the protocol, but in the case of V3 if there’s not enough liquidity to sell the entire lot without slippage a partial trade is made, the remaining balance would be retained until the hop period has passed. As long as the amounts are kept within reasonable ranges the price protections in Uniswap should make frontrunning attacks financially infeasible, so the protocol would be able to get close to market price on burns and they’d be on a predictable cadence. Again, this is an early prototype and needs team reviews and audits, but might offer a solution that allows for setting the surplus buffer at a high value while still getting controlled burns.

content.content: I stayed out of this thread until now except to vote NO. Reasoning as follows: First I understand that for many people the flop/flap mechanics had and HAVE an appeal and are part of the whitepaper design.  But if you look back at the scientific data here perhaps I can change your view that the existing flop/flap mechanics are not just inefficient but growingly flawed from a existential perspective.   Maker early on started off with a 1B cap while only having what < 100M DAI in existence.  The thinking here Maker could lose a chunk of this 100M and still have adequate MKR market cap to fill this hole.   This proved to be true except during and after Black Thursday.   Maker with a 600M Market cap at the time and 150M DAI outstanding ended up with a surplus hole of 6M and DAI liquidity so terribly bad that governance halted flops leaving DAI holders with a more than 6% hole in the collateral backing of the existing DAI for a week putting DAI holders at risk of loss during that time.   Once a USDC vault was opened up and sufficient bidders for MKR came on line we flopped what 20K+ MKR to raise 6M DAI at a rough average (off top of my head numbers here btw) price of 280DAI/MKR which we have been buying back with flaps at roughly 2500DAI/MKR.   The cost to the MKR market cap on a 6M Surplus hole was about 320M (price decrease from 600-280) or over a 50% hit to the total market cap to fill a 6% surplus buffer loss.   The final tab for Black Thursday to MKR holders (6M-50M) or about 44M DAI profit lost due to flopping low and flapping high.   This isn’t just terrible performance - it is almost non-existent performance of the market cap to fill any sort of hole in the SB.   Maker would have done far better selling 5-10K MKR to raise 5-10M to fill the surplus buffer before hand.     Even better would have been to float a fixed term bond at 10%/yr for 6M because we could have paid it off in months and not diluted at all. What this event showed us was that even in the best of times MKR market cap is going to get crushed trying to fill a DAI surplus buffer gap and that the flap/flop mechanics are guaranteed to buy high and sell lower… At this time the MKR market cap is barely 2B and DAI floated is ~10B.   The market cap of Maker is 20% of the entire DAI supply now vs. before Black Thursday when it was 400% the DAI supply.    Based on past experience even a 100M surplus loss (which would lead to flopping for 40M) would cost the protocol over 1B in market cap. The above DATA then means that Maker should be looking to enact a better model to sell MKR high and buy it low. FYI while a MKRDAI v2 does this over the entire price range.   So does a Uniswap v3 contract. Literally Maker could provide market liquidity over a price band which basically will buy MKR low and sell it high.  These AMMs would buy low sell higher over and over again earning fees and at lesat with the v2 autocompounding.   A v3 contract concentrates liquidity so you get a much better return over a v2, but a v2 has liquidity over the entire range of price.   The whole point of these AMMs is if they are funded in a set and forget mode - they are by definition programmed to buy low and sell high.    Also in the v2 contract there is a price low that can’t be exceeded that there will always be liquidity at all price points, and the only price high is the limit on DAI that could exist in the contract at the time. Frankly if it comes to a choice.   flap for MKR or just take the DAI and pair it with MKR to stick into a v2 or v3 Uniswap or burn the MKR I’d rather put MKR and DAI it in a v2 or a v3 every time. Why?  Because if left alone these contracts earn fees providing return to the DAO based on treasury assets (which btw the 84K MKR sitting there is earning us nothing).   Secondly, they always buy low and sell high doing exactly what the DAO needs them to do for proper liquidity expansion and contraction. The DAO can take both MKR and DAI and earn return, but instead we choose to effectively drain DAI from the surplus to extinguish MKR via a flawed flap/buy mechanism only to feel good when we know the flop mechanism is not just seriously flawed but an existential threat.   This is like cutting off your arm and your foot while trying to build a house.   Why not keep and use the ARM and the FOOT and build a better house using them together. Last note.  Everyone is focused on fixing the flapper,  is the flopper rate limited?

content.content: Overview With the executive vote that got scheduled yesterday we are going to have the Surplus Buffer set to 250 MM so no further burning will happen anytime soon (discussion). This has been done as a counteraction of the events of last friday and is meant as a short term fix. @hexonaut from the Protocol Engineering Team already has drafted a more sustainable solution that has the potential to be activated on mainnet soon. This will introduce rate limiting into the flapper, limiting the number of parallel auctions. However, multiple ideas of how to replace the current Flapper have been floating around in the past. This Signal Request is about to find out if we  want to keep the Surplus Buffer at a level that prevents MKR burning and come up and implement a totally different solution (dutch auctions, other adjustments to the Flapper like adding a minimum price…) before going back to burning (Do Nothing) want to get back to the previous decided path of lerping up the Surplus Buffer to 90 MM by 1 MM every week (discussion) - but also adding the above patch to the Flapper (Apply Rate Limiting and get back to burning asap)   Option 1: Do Nothing - Prevent Burning This would be done by just keeping the Surplus Buffer at a really high level, making it highly unlikely that the System Surplus spilling over the Surplus Buffer. No actions need to be taken, but we might need to increase the Surplus Buffer in the future. This is the option if you don’t want a short term fix to be applied on the current MKR burn mechanics but instead wait for a more long term solution (dutch auctions, replacing the mechanism entirely with something totally different, ….)  Pros  Avoid auctioning MKR with the potential for high slippage. all income will flow into the System Surplus, pilling up a high buffer for bad debt on the protocol   Cons  No more MKR burning until we have a replacement implementation in place During a market decline, the burn feature causes demand on buying MKR (and destroying MKR) to support the price. Indirectly this protects the hat as the economic price for a governance attack is elevated. suspending the MKR burn for a long term will also return less value for MKR holders as there is no intrinsic MKR-demand by protocol   Option 2: Introduce Rate Limiting to the Flapper This would modify the Flapper-Contract by introducing a rate limit so we can control the amount of parallel running flap-auctions. If we generate a lot of unforseen income (through e.g. liquidations), we will still have the same amount of flap-auctions, but they would be spread over a longer time instead of happening simultaneously. The likelihood for 0-bids is thereby reduced. There is already a Pull Request on the Flapper open by @hexonaut - the changes are pretty simple. After the changes have been applied to the mainnet contracts, we would reactivate the previously installed SB-lerp so we would continue with the path we took before the urgency exec. This option does not limit our future options to go for dutch auctions or other improvements in the long run.  Pros  can bring the burning back online rather soon compared to other solutions while mitigating the 0-bid problems we encountered in the past if we run into a large wave of liquidations, the System Surplus will get large and not get melted down instantly - providing a larger buffer in case we run into bad debt for the protocol   Cons  we will still keep a decent amount of discount for keepers (historically between 3-4%) as the Flapper cannot be as efficient as e.g. dutch auctions   How shall we move on with the deactivated Flapper?     Do nothing - let’s not burn any more MKR until we have a long term solution in place Introduce Rate Limiting into the Flapper and bring back MKR burning asap Abstain     0 voters      Next steps The Polls will run until 2022-02-04T14:00:00Z; its outcomes will either result in an on-chain-poll assuming the outcome of the poll deems it necessary or its intermediate results is going to be taken to another initiative - another signal, onchain-poll or urgency executive. PS: thanks @JustinCase  and @dumitru  for collaborating on this Signal Request

content.content: I am voting do nothing because I think a robust long term solution is more valuable than short term burn, even at great prices. Getting carried awat by burn FOMO can lead to poor decision making. Particularly, I think if we go back to burning, we are unlikely to address improving the burner in the future, and this will be a lost opportunity. Firstly, I don’t believe there is much point in trying to speculate about the market price or the best timings to burn, since markets are impossible to predict. There is just as much potential upside as there is downside with burning a little bit later down the line, as far as price movement goes. The current system, as well as the dutch auction system is not a good fit for a burn mechanism is my opinion for the following reasons:  Unnecessary excess gas costs (both for protocol and for network) Unnecessary keeper overhead Unnecessary oracle overhead Unnecessary slippage risk  Excess surplus can be lerped into a continous DAI liquidity pool that offers swaps at a fixed price. The price can be automated by targeting market price periodically, or decided manually by executive vote. This already greatly reduces oracle usage. Instead of having to kick and deal for every 30K dai lot, an arbitrageur can take bites off the liquidity pool at any size, by calling a single function. This reduces keeper overhead and removes time sensitivity in upkeep of the burn mechanism. This also allows market makers to burn MKR as fast as possible when the price is right, giving the protocol more efficient access to capital. The currently proposed fix slows things down considerably. This would be even faste rthan dutch auctions. English auctions have a built in slippage of 3-4%, while dutch auctions have a timer that increases the slippage the longer keepers take to act. This is important for vault liquidations because we need to offload risky debt as fast as possible. For burning surplus cash, this is completely unnecesary complexity that introduces systematic risk for no good reason. If we pick a fixed price close to market periodically, then of course volatility can deal against us and carry virtual slippage too, but there is symetric upside to this downside, and for all practical purposes, these outcomes will always be random in aggregate. The built in slippage on both auction mechanisms on the othe hand is systematic negative slippage. Paying oracles on a per lot basis to give the most up to date price does not really provide us with any protection to these random market movements thus it is a waste of gas and bad for the whole Ethereum ecosystem. Let’s try to be more focused on the long term approach!
